description: From Middle English good, from Old English gōd, from Proto-West Germanic *gōd, from Proto-Germanic *gōdaz, from Proto-Indo-European *gʰedʰ- (“to unite, be associated, suit”). Cognate with Russian го́дный (gódnyj, “fit, well-suited, good for; (coll.) good”), год (god), "year", via "suitable time". Not related to the word god.

entries.meaning: Acting in the interest of what is beneficial, ethical, or moral.
examples: good intentions
a good swimmer

entries.meaning: Able to be depended on for the discharge of obligations incurred; of unimpaired credit; used with for.
examples: Can you lend me fifty dollars? You know I'm good for it.
Be good while your mother and I are out.
Were you a good boy for the babysitter?

entries.meaning: (US) Satisfied or at ease; not requiring more.
examples: Would you like a glass of water? — I'm good.
[Are] you good? — Yeah, I'm fine.
Gimme another beer! — I think you're good.

entries.meaning: (colloquial, with with) Accepting of, OK with
examples: My mother said she's good with me being alone with my date as long as she's met them first.
The soup is rather spicy. Are you good with that, or would you like something else?

entries.meaning: Useful for a particular purpose; functional.
examples: it’s a good watch;  the flashlight batteries are still good
a good worker
in good sooth
The food was very good.
The food was very good.
Eat a good dinner so you will be ready for the big game tomorrow.

entries.meaning: Of food or other perishable products, still fit for use; not yet expired, stale, rotten, etc.
examples: The bread is still good.

entries.meaning: Valid, of worth, capable of being honoured.
examples: This coupon is good for a free doughnut.
This theory still holds good even if much higher temperatures are assumed.
Exercise and a varied diet are good for you.
We had a good time.
a good omen;  good weather
a person's good name
a good job

entries.meaning: (colloquial, when with and) Very, extremely. See good and.
examples: The soup is good and hot.
I'm good when you are.
The reports are good to go.
Good Friday, Good Wednesday, the Good Book
all in good time
a good while longer;  a good number of seeds;  A good part of his day was spent shopping.  It will be a good while longer until he's done.  He's had a good amount of troubles, he has.

entries.meaning: Full; entire; at least as much as.
examples: This hill will take a good hour and a half to climb.  The car was a good ten miles away.

description: From Middle English goode (“good, well”, adverb), from the adjective. Compare Dutch goed (“good, well”, adverb), German gut (“good, well”, adverb), Danish godt (“good, well”, adverb), Swedish godt (“good, well”, adverb), all from the adjective.

examples: The boy done good. (did well)

description: From Middle English good, god, from Old English gōd (“a good thing, advantage, benefit, gift; good, goodness, welfare; virtue, ability, doughtiness; goods, property, wealth”), from Proto-Germanic *gōdą (“goods, belongings”), from Proto-Indo-European *gʰedʰ-, *gʰodʰ- (“to unite, be associated, suit”). Compare German Gut (“item of merchandise; estate; property”).

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The forces or behaviours that are the enemy of evil. Usually consists of helping others and general benevolence.
examples: Antonyms: bad, evil

entries.meaning: (countable) A result that is positive in the view of the speaker.
examples: Antonym: bad

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The abstract instantiation of goodness; that which possesses desirable qualities, promotes success, welfare, or happiness, is serviceable, fit, excellent, kind, benevolent, etc.
examples: The best is the enemy of the good.
He is an influence for good on those girls.

entries.meaning: (countable, usually in the plural) An item of merchandise.

description: From Middle English goden, godien, from Old English gōdian (“to improve, get better; make better; endow, enrich”), from Proto-West Germanic *gōdōn (“to make better, improve”), from Proto-Germanic *gōdaz (“good, favourable”).

verbs.description: good (third-person singular simple present goods, present participle gooding, simple past and past participle gooded) (now chiefly dialectal)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, now) To thrive; fatten; prosper; improve.
(transitive) To make good; turn to good; improve.
(transitive) To do good to (someone); benefit; cause to improve or gain.

description: From English dialectal, from Middle English *goden, of North Germanic origin, related to Swedish göda (“to fatten, fertilise, battle”), Danish gøde (“to fertilise, battle”), ultimately from the adjective. See above.

verbs.description: good (third-person singular simple present goods, present participle gooding, simple past and past participle gooded)

entries.meaning: (transitive, now chiefly dialectal, Scotland) To furnish with dung; manure; fatten with manure; fertilise.
examples: Nature was like itself , in it , in the world : God hath taken it in from the barren downs , and gooded it : his choice did not find , but make it thus
